help.description: Databases gives speed and flexibility for the whole team: Fast artist tools, Complicated present and future predictions can be made with historical data available. Good databases I like to use are usually MongoDB and MySQL databases development, replication, backups, optimization. MySQL is create for relational data where MongoDB for fast and unsorted/dynamic data.
help.title: Database Driven Pipelines

help.description: Very few people like to clean and even fewer like to clean other people belongings. Plus it takes time and a good understanding of the data you're about to clean. For that reason, it's best to structure the files/data in a way that makes it easier to clean later. Or even better, deploy smart and automated cleaning process. All of which to help backup, archive and monitoring of data.
help.title: File System IT & Cleanup

help.description: Pipeline and IT using many services in the backend to help productions. Deploying and managing these services can be by deploying services using ESXi, Virtual machines, Docker.
help.title: VM's & Dockers Services

help.description: Management, deploying and monitoring of render-farm can be done smartly, using automated emails/alert, production-driven queuing systems, expanding to the cloud and overall making wrangler life easier.
help.title: Render Farm Deployment and Management

help.description: Integrating Shotgun into the artist's workflow helps the production team to be on top of everything. Integration in tools, workflows, triggers for automation. While Shotgun pages are great, many studios end-up building custom Dashboard to better monitor their productions, with more complicated queries and tracking..
help.title: Shotgun Integration & Advance Dashboards

help.description: Monitoring and building metrics of the studio resources is key for savings and smart growth. Knowing the numbers behind licenses, servers, workstations helps so much. Using Grafana, Prometheus and Sentry services to collect and monitor backend/frontend services.
help.title: Resources Monitoring & Metrics

help.description: There are many great render engines out there. Each has requires optimizations and a pipeline around it to push the render times down. Optimizations are usually caching assets, creating proxies, pre-converting textures. .
help.title: Rendering Optimizations

help.description: Developing proprietary asset-frameworks is one of my passions. I put a lot of love and a rich feature set in those. To name a few of the features: Agnostic to DCC/OS. Each publish is a version, each version can be linked to other versions/asset/take, each version has a metadata, supports approval/rejection. supports smart disk-space cleanup, post-processing, farm publishing, pre-publish asset checks... and much more.
help.title: Asset Management: Proprietary NextGen Framework

help.description: It can be somewhat "boring" area in production... having a colour-accurate pipeline from end to end is the only way to guarantee quality delivery of images. Images coming out of Photoshop should flow to rendering with the correct colorspace, with as little assumptions made on the way. Add to that calibrated monitors and you're in business!.
help.title: Color Accurate From Start to End

help.description: Artists need custom tools and support. Many steps and processes can be simplified. Free the artists do focus on "art" and less fighting tech challenges along the way, that makes a good goal. All of the DCC could use more tooling: Maya, Nuke, Katana, Unity, Mari, Zbrush, Mudbox...
help.title: Custom Artists Tools For All DCCs

node.excerpt: Production comes with challenges. We resolve them with workflows, communication, training/education and good code.

node.html:
“I would like to make a film to tell children "it's good to be alive"”

― Hayao Miyazaki

The animation team wants to bring the characters to life and play. A good pipeline let's them use their time to tell the character's story as apposed to dealing with the technical steps.

Challenges and Solutions

  • Create rigs that are fun and expressive.
  • Keep the rigs light and fast or use LODs.
  • Rigs are never perfect, animation should be able to correct shapes.
  • Automate caches once animation-take is approve. No need to re-open scene-file.
  • Separate creative approval and technical approval steps.
  • GPU rendering to QC the shots before lighting.

“Build it and they will come”

― Field of Dreams

The asset team build, paint, shade, groom and rig the assets while hitting the creative and technical requirements.

Challenges and Solutions

  • Constantly updating assets without breaking downstream, using approval steps.
  • Modular-framework for working with large environments such as Pixar's USD.
  • Clear tracking of asset/version and their Episode/Sequences/Shots.
  • One publish interface to generate all LOD for an asset.
  • Understand the asset needs right from the previs stage.

“If you type ‘Google’ into Google, you can break the internet.”

― The IT Crowd

The IT team goal is to keep the server and services working - 99.9% of the time. IT challenges are balancing management and deployment of hardware&software, storage, security, high-availability servers, hardware evaluation and budget.

Challenges and Solutions

  • Keep track of disk-space and the context/usage of each file and folder.
  • Monitor the health of the infrastructure. Alert when things go down.
  • Keep track over usage of licenses and other resources throughout the day.
  • Docker for lightweight services makes for easy maintenance and upgrades.

“The spice must flow”

― Dune by Frank Herbert

The pipeline team continuously work to stream-line common-tasks while making other more complex-tasks doable. Finding stable and flexible solutions is key so we can keep building layers of solutions as the pipeline grows and expend.

Challenges and Solutions

  • Use Agile development methodology for short&clear development cycles.
  • Share Pipeline's task and priorities with everyone. Transparency counts.
  • Track reported and not-yet-reported bugs (sentry.io).
  • Collect metrics of used tools and issues. This data helps making choices.
  • Code review and unittest counts! Control-Review (gitlab) / Unittest (pytest).
  • Package deployment to buffer changes Package Deployment (rez).

“That's a pie crust promise; easily made, easily broken!”

― Mary Poppins

Production *sometimes* can feel like "herding cats". Always keeping track of milestones, deadlines, reviews, staffing and client, while communicating and juggling priorities. All at once.

Challenges and Solutions

  • Task-tracking software that is well integrated with artists workflow.
  • Metrics-Dashboard to keep track of the of production schedule and trends.
  • Clear workflows as to what's the next step and who's doing.
  • Automation between steps to keep the flow going.

“Darkness cannot drive out darkness: only light can do that”

― Martin Luther King

The lighting, compositing and rendering team are all about the race to the finish line. Been on the end of the production, so often they get the "growing pain" of all the departments before them.

Challenges and Solutions

  • Keep the scenes light&fast to load. Using proxies and cached data.
  • Publish/Load lighting and compositing templates.
  • GPU rendering to allow more iterations.
  • Robust and scalable farm that can cycle the jobs in a timely manner.
  • Collect data and monitor the farm to know where to improve.
  • Help artists reduce render time and optimize render-time.
“Once upon a time, in a land far far away...”
